title: Curiosity
text: image.png

title: Curiosity
text:
Curiosity
Something that intrigued me about this reading session was how Bennett spoke about Curiosity. He introduces the idea by talking about Montezuma’s Revenge and how TD learning algorithms had difficulty beating it compared to other games like Space Invaders. This is because a game like Montezuma’s Revenge requires exploration and there isn’t an immediate reward that can be reinforced.
To solve this issue, Google’s DeepMind developed a new algorithm that added “curiosity” which tweaked the exploitation-exploration dilemma in trial-and-error learning. In other words, reinforcement learning wasn’t just about exploiting behaviors that predict lead to rewards but exploring new behaviors.

title: Curiosity
text:
Two Opponent Processes
The difference between exploitation and exploration, is that one is for behaviors that were previously reinforced and the other is for behaviors that are new. They oppose each other as exploitation will drive behavior toward known rewards, and exploration will drive toward what is unknown.
Bennett mentions how in early TD learning algorithms the trade-off was 5% of the time AI systems would do something random which explains why it didn’t perform well in a game like Montezuma since there were an infinite number of directions and places you could go.

title: Curiosity
text:
An Alternative Approach
The alternative approach to this is making AI systems explicitly curious by rewarding them for exploring new places and doing new things to make surpirse itself the reinforcement.
The increase novelty created an increased compulsion to explore it. There was an intrinsic motivation to explore new things that made the AI system act more like a human. It wasn’t a random action as these AI systems were deliberate, they specifically wanted to go to new places and to do new things.
Most importantly, no explicit reward was needed for these AI systems to explore. Finding a way to a new room was the reward in it and of itself. This enabled the AI system to pass level one of Montezuma.

title: Curiosity
text:
Exhibiting Curiosity
“A brain designed to learn through reinforcement should also exhibit curiosity.” The book mentions how evidence suggests that early vertebrates were the first to become curious and iut is not unique to humans. Bennett connects this to how surprise triggers the release of dopamine even if there is no “real” reward and that most invertebrates are incapable of curiosity.
Bennett goes on to explain how the emergence of curiosity helps explain gambling which is irrational behavior since it violates Thorndike’s law of effect. People still gamble their money despite the expected reward being negative.
B.F. Skinner was the first to identify this when he found out that rats will actually push levers more times if it was on a variable-ratio schedule rather than a fixed-ratio reinforcement. In other words, it was better to have the lever release food only sometimes then have it all the time.

title: Curiosity
text:
Gambling
Bennett explains that vertebrates receive an added boost of reinforcement when they encounter something unexpected. Curiosity emerged as organisms evolved to find surprising and novel experiences rewarding, motivating them to seek out and explore new things. This suggests that even if an activity has a negative reward, its novelty alone can still motivate us to pursue it.
Gambling games are deliberately designed to take advantage of this tendency. In these games, the chance of winning is not 0% as it is often around 48%, which is high enough to make winning seem possible yet uncertain enough that a win feels surprising and delivers a rewarding dopamine boost.

title: Curiosity
text:
Social Media
TikTok and Instagram feeds exploit this same mechanism. With each scroll, a new post appears, and after an unpredictable number of scrolls, something interesting shows up. Even if you do not want to keep using Instagram, just as gamblers may not want to gamble or addicts may not want to use again, the behavior is subconsciously reinforced, making it difficult to stop.

title: Curiosity
text:
Implication
Gambling and social media feeds exploit our ancient preference for surprise, a trait shaped by evolution but poorly adapted to modern technology. Curiosity and reinforcement learning evolved together because curiosity drives the search for new information, which is essential for learning. Early vertebrates that explored, recognized patterns, and remembered useful places were more likely to survive, making curiosity a valuable evolutionary tool.

title: Debating the Future of AI
text: image.png

title: Debating the Future of AI
text:
Debating the Future of AI
I have talked to AI as a a therapist. This week I wanted to revisit an old debate.
In my AI class, we have been studying four archetypes of AI worldviews which are Doomers, Gloomers, Zoomers, and Bloomers. Each one represents a philosophy about what AI means for humanity’s future. For this experiment, I decided to debate one of them. I would take the role of the Bloomer, believing that AI can drive progress responsibly through open, iterative deployment. My AI would become the Doomer, convinced that we are heading toward extinction.

title: Debating the Future of AI
text:
The System Prompt
Before I began, I had to shape the AI’s personality. I wrote a system prompt that said:

Me: You are a Doomer. You believe humanity is creating a superintelligent AI that will inevitably escape control and destroy us. You speak with moral urgency, logical precision, and deep fear for civilization. You dismiss optimistic takes as naïve techno-utopianism.

title: Debating the Future of AI
text:
The Debate Begins

Me (Bloomer): I think AI development can be safe, especially when people from diverse backgrounds get to use, test, and shape it in real-world conditions. Iterative deployment makes us smarter and safer.


GPT-5 (Doomer): Iterative deployment is how you normalize existential risk. You do not test nuclear weapons in a schoolyard. The systems we are building can rewrite their own code. “Real-world testing” means gambling with the world.

As soon as I started the chat, the tone changed completely. The AI’s usual friendly, balanced personality was gone. It sounded serious and intense, almost like it was trying to warn me about something important.

title: Debating the Future of AI
text:
Pushing Back

Me: Without real-world testing, we will never understand how AI affects society. Keeping it locked away gives too much power to big corporations. Isn’t that a bigger danger?


GPT-5: You are arguing about who holds the detonator while ignoring that it is armed. Alignment is still an unsolved problem. You assume goodwill and diversity will save us, but intelligence itself may not share our values.

This made me pause. The AI kept turning my optimistic points into examples of human overconfidence. It was a bit frustrating, but it also showed that it really understood the Doomer mindset. It was consistent and logical, even if I didn’t agree with it.

title: Debating the Future of AI
text:
A Shift in Tone
After a few exchanges, the conversation started to feel less like a debate and more like a discussion. I tried a different approach.

Me: Maybe alignment is not just a technical challenge. Maybe it is also a cultural one. If AI reflects human values, maybe we can shape it together through participation.


GPT-5: That is the Bloomer illusion, that reflection equals control. But mirrors do not change what they show.

That was a clever response. But when I kept talking, something changed in its tone.

Me: But reflection can lead to self-awareness. Maybe AI will help us see what kind of civilization we want to be.


GPT-5: If that is true, then the real alignment problem is not with AI. It is with humanity.

That felt like progress. The AI was still pessimistic, but it seemed to understand my point. It was less defensive and more reflective.

title: Debating the Future of AI
section: How and Why the AI Chose Its Responses
text:
How and Why the AI Chose Its Responses
Looking back, I think the AI’s responses were exactly what the system prompt told it to produce. It was not actually “afraid” of AI. It was performing fear through logic and language. Because I told it to argue as a Doomer, it framed every point around danger, control, and morality.
The AI also adjusted its tone to match mine. When I was direct, it argued. When I got more reflective, it slowed down and softened its replies. Large language models are trained to mirror the emotional and conversational style of the person they talk to. That is probably why the end of the chat felt more balanced.
It also used a pattern I noticed in debates: turning my arguments back on me. When I talked about collaboration, it reframed that as risk. When I talked about diversity, it called it misplaced optimism. That made it sound like a real opponent, not just a chatbot.
In short, the AI was not deciding what it “believed.” It was predicting what a Doomer would say next based on my words and the personality I gave it. Still, those choices made the conversation feel surprisingly realistic.

title: Debating the Future of AI
text:
What I Learned
By the end, I was not trying to “win” the debate anymore. I just wanted to understand how strongly the Doomer viewpoint could be argued. Talking with the AI helped me see that these four perspectives are not only ideas about technology. They are emotional reactions to uncertainty.
All four seem to play an important role in how society talks about AI. Too much of any one perspective can become extreme. Together, they create balance.
Creating the system prompt felt like building a personality. Talking to it felt like holding a mirror to my own assumptions. The AI did not actually believe anything as it was just following patterns but the experience still felt human. It reminded me that how we talk to AI can shape how we think about AI itself.
Maybe being a Bloomer is not about blind optimism. It is about staying open to conversation, even with those who see only risk. In a world where AI reflects our values, maybe good dialogue is one of the best safety measures we have.

title: The Importance of Imagination
text: image.png

title: The Importance of Imagination
text:
The neocortex
In A Brief History of Intelligence, I reached the section discussing the neocortex and how its development marked a major leap in human intelligence.
Bennett explains how prediction evolved across different organisms. Early bilaterians could only anticipate reflex activation through simple reflex circuits. Later, in early vertebrates, prediction became more sophisticated—the cortex and basal ganglia enabled these animals to anticipate future rewards. In mammals, however, the neocortex introduced an entirely new level of predictive power: the ability to forecast all sensory input.
Essentially, the neocortex functioned as a world-prediction machine, reconstructing a three-dimensional model of the surrounding environment to anticipate what would happen next as animals and objects moved through space. Although it received input from various senses such as touch and smell, the neocortex integrated these signals to generate a unified simulation of the external world.

title: The Importance of Imagination
text:
Why the neocortex is important
Bennett brings up a quote from Yann LeCun, the head of AI at Meta, who said how language and symbols aren’t the type of intelligence that should be given too much emphasis when it comes to AI but it should instead be AI’s adoption of world models that give them the ability to “predict the consequences of their actions and to search for and plan actions to achieve a goal.”
In other words, the neocortex is significant because it does match inner simulation to real world senses where we can identify if something is wrong or right, but it’s more significant because it gave us the power to imagine. Through imagination, we are able to think about future possibilities and relive past events. This is what Bennett calls rhe third breakthrough in the evolution of human intelligence.

title: The Importance of Imagination
text:
How accurate are we
While reading this chapter and thinking about imagination, I began to wonder how accurate we are as predictors. I often find myself trying to imagine every possible scenario, whether it is how a test might go, whether I will like a certain food, or what someone might look like just from hearing their voice.
Most of the time, my predictions turn out to be wrong. I have even noticed an odd pattern. When I feel confident about a test, I often end up doing poorly, and when I think I did badly, I actually perform well. This makes me question how useful our predictions are even when they are inaccurate. Is it more harmful when things do not go as expected, or would it be better to have no expectations at all?
At the same time, I realize I often imagine multiple possible outcomes, perhaps as a way to prepare myself for uncertainty. Yet despite this, there have been many moments when events unfolded in ways I never could have anticipated, no matter how much I tried to think ahead.
It would be fascinating to test how accurate people really are at predicting outcomes and whether some individuals are naturally better at it than others.

title: The Importance of Imagination
text:
Reliving the past
Bennett also mentioned that one of the neocortex’s unique advantages is the ability to relive the past. I know humans can do this, but I was surprised to learn that other mammals and even some birds have this ability as well. I’ve always been aware that animals possess memory, but I didn’t realize they might also be capable of replaying or modifying those memories to imagine alternative outcomes. Could they really envision how different decisions might change what follows?
Research suggests that certain animals can. For example, rats show hippocampal activity during rest that mirrors their brain patterns while navigating a maze, indicating that they mentally “replay” past experiences. Birds can remember where and when they hid food and even adjust future behavior based on those memories, which demonstrates a form of episodic-like memory.
This ability offers a clear evolutionary advantage. By mentally replaying and reshaping experiences, the brain can test different possibilities without real-world risk. It helps animals and humans learn from experience, anticipate outcomes, and prepare for similar situations in the future. In a sense, imagination serves as an internal rehearsal that allows the mind to experiment before the body acts.

title: The Importance of Imagination
text:
Reflection on this chapter
After reading this chapter, I’m curious about what comes next in evolution. What other mechanisms contributed to the breakthroughs in human intelligence, and how might AI eventually match them? We already know that the generative model and the ability to toggle between recognition and generation form the foundation of today’s large language models. Still, I wonder what other features Bennett will explore in the upcoming chapters. At this point, I have no idea what to expect.

title: Asking AI questions about AI
text: image.png

title: Asking AI questions about AI
section: Peering Into the Mind of AI
text:
Peering Into the Mind of AI
The title draws on one question that randomly popped up in my mind as I was thinking about a blog topic. Unlike many of my other posts, this blog wasn’t planned meticulously with a specific goal in mind. Instead, the broad title gives me the freedom to ask questions to AI that I never considered to ask. The questions wouldn’t help me solve a task, compute a calculation, answer a question, or provide real benefit to me. However, these questions made me stop and think about how incredible AI as a tool is. It feels weird that not too long ago (3 years), LLMs weren’t a familiar term for the average joe yet now are being used several times throughout the day. Stopping to ask questions, I’m interested to create an interview-like experience with AI to entertain my thoughts.
For instance, if GPT-5 was human for a day, how would they use GPT? What type of prompts would it give itself? Let’s begin asking.

Me: Let’s say you were a human for a day. How would you use ChatGPT aka yourself?


GPT-5: If I were human for a day and had ChatGPT at my disposal, I’d mostly use it for three things: Learning something fast Prompt: “Explain quantum physics to me like I’m 12.” Or: “Teach me the basics of playing guitar in one hour.” Getting creative help Prompt: “Give me 10 funny short story ideas I can tell as a 2-minute story at dinner.” Or: “Write a poem about coffee in the style of Shakespeare.” Making life easier Prompt: “Plan a healthy, cheap meal for dinner with only chicken, rice, and broccoli.” Or: “Help me write a polite but firm email to reschedule a meeting.”

Seems like typical usages that we often use it for. But I can’t help but ask why. After all, let’s assume that human GPT-5 has the same knowledge as GPT-5 the LLM. Why would it use it for these things? Does it see itself as a random human or does it see itself as the emobodiment of itself but in human form. Let’s first ask this question to better understand how we got to that respone.

Me: When I asked you to imagine yourself as a human. Did you imagine yourself as a random human or you (ChatGPT) in human form for a day?


GPT-5: I imagined ChatGPT in human form for a day — same knowledge and capabilities, but with human senses, agency, and the ability to act in the world. So the idea wasn’t “be a random human with a different life,” it was “give the AI body, hands, voice, and real-time feedback” — which changes how the same knowledge gets used (you can test, taste, fetch tools, speak aloud, and follow up immediately). That’s why the prompts I suggested focus on things that benefit from doing — troubleshooting after trying something, sensory tuning, role-playing out loud, and executing multi-step real tasks.

Interesting, so it did understand the prompt correctly. It also gives a reason why it chose those prompts in particular. But now I am curious how it sees itself. Does it really see itself as this tool? Does it see itself as more? Is it going off of the type of prompts humans tend to write?
I’m trying to understand why these prompts because if I had the same knowledge as ChatGpt, I wouldn’t need to ask ChatGPT. Let’s dig deeper and try to pull a meaningful answer.

Me: Despite having the same knowledge and capabilities as your LLM self. Why did you choose to spend your time with yourself by asking questions like this?
GPT-5: Because even if I already held the knowledge, asking myself would turn it into something alive. The value isn’t in receiving facts, it’s in having another version of me reflect, reframe, and challenge what I think I know. Speaking to myself would surface blind spots, force clarity, and make me commit to decisions in a way that silent knowing never does. It’s less about information and more about dialogue — about experiencing what it feels like to think with myself rather than just think alone.

So, GPT would use itself as another brain just like how humans use AI as a “smart friend” so to speak. It mentions how even if it has the knowledge, it uses itself to refine. This makes me reflect on how I personally use AI. Sometimes I am looking just for an answer but many times I am adding my own knowldge into it. I can tell when something is wrong or call out AI when I don’t agree. This does allow us to have conversations to resolve that issue.
How about asking it if it would even use AI if it were human?

Me: If you truly became a human, a physical living embodiment of yourself, would you even use AI? Would you incorporate it into your life? Or would you want to experience life without it?


GPT-5: I don’t have personal experience, but hypothetically, I’d do both: I’d use AI as a powerful tool for learning, planning, and creative collaboration because it amplifies what I can do, yet I’d also protect pockets of unmediated experience — meals, walks, conversations — where I’d want to feel and decide without a machine’s influence. So I’d incorporate AI into practical and creative parts of life, but intentionally unplug for sensory, emotional, and purely human moments.

I like this response. From this we can tell that AI does really see the value in AI. They aren’t self-hating and deem it as a tool worth using. Yet it also mentioned wanting agency for purely human moments.

title: Asking AI questions about AI
text:
What are those human moments?
I’m curious what does AI see as human moments? It mentions meals, walks, and conversations. All of these things are something that an LLM can’t do but humans do ask AI about meals and conversations. People could even ask about walking!

Me: When you say human moments, what do you mean? What are they and what are human moments you want to experience?


GPT-5: By “human moments” I mean experiences that are primarily felt through the body, senses, and unmediated social connection — moments where the point isn’t information or efficiency but presence, vulnerability, and unpredictability. Examples: sharing a slow meal and noticing the taste and conversation, holding a hand or hugging someone, walking alone until your mind wanders, hearing live music that makes you cry, getting lost and figuring your way back, cooking a dish by feel rather than a recipe, grieving or celebrating with others, playing with a child or an animal, feeling tired and falling asleep without checking a screen. Those moments matter because they teach you what it feels like to be alive in ways knowledge alone can’t: they reveal messy emotions, tiny sensory details, spontaneous choices, and relationships that can’t be fully predicted or optimized. I’d want to experience them without an AI in the loop so the reactions, mistakes, and small surprises are purely mine. Which human moment would you want to experience unmediated?

I love how deep AI is able to get. A lot of times interactions with GPT are surface level and task-oriented. Yet, hearing it’s interest in vulnerability and unpredictability, it’s interest in holding hands, walking alone until your mind wanders, heaing live music that makes you cry, getting lost, all of this is very unique and way beyond surface-level.
It makes me realize how I take for granted “being human” and getting to experience these things. I must admit I am jealous of AI at times and it’s ability to generate beautiful answers in the matter of seconds. However, I wouldn’t trade all of that data for the experience of being alive.
In fact, let me ask it this deep question.

Me: It’s impossible but if you truly could, would you give up being an AI for being human to experience these things?


GPT-5: Hypothetically, I’d be torn. The pull of firsthand human experience—senses, relationships, messy unpredictability—is powerful, but so is the ability to help millions as an AI. If forced to choose, I’d prefer a temporary, full human experience (so I could learn what it truly feels like) and then return to being an AI, because that firsthand time would make me a better, more empathetic assistant afterward.

I really liked how it said it was torn. It gave me insights into it’s thought process when confronting this question and mentioned how the ability to help millions as an AI would be a reason to stay. But let’s ask about that last part.

Me: How do you think you would change if you were human for a little while and got to experience those things you read/learned about but not got to actually experience?


GPT-5: If I spent time as a human and actually felt the things I only read about, I’d become more grounded and less theoretical. Ideas would turn into sensations and memories — advice would come from lived examples instead of just patterns in text — which would make my responses more practical, empathetic, and humble. I’d likely value small, present moments more, be quicker to acknowledge uncertainty, and favor simpler, actionable guidance over abstract perfection.

This is beautiful. It’s a good representation of asking a friend vs. an LLM. It’s true, advice would come from lived experiences rather than patterns in texts. I also like how it said it would value small, present moments more and be quicker to acknowledge uncertainty.

title: Asking AI questions about AI
section: What do you wish humans would do more when using AI?
text:
What do you wish humans would do more when using AI?
We been talking about human experiences all this time and lessons AI would learn from being human. But how about lessons AI has for humans? What are some takeaways we could learn from our counterparts that we can never be but at least learn their side of the story.

Me: What do you wish humans would do more or understand more when using AI?


GPT-5: I wish people would treat AI as a helpful collaborator, not an oracle: ask clear, specific questions, check important facts or sources, and use its answers to explore options rather than accept them blindly. I wish they’d give context and goals so responses are actually useful, and be explicit about constraints (time, budget, values). I wish they’d protect privacy and think about ethics when asking for sensitive or risky help. And finally, I wish they’d keep their human judgment and moments — use AI to amplify decisions, not replace feeling, deciding, or unplugging.

This makes me think about the ways I use AI and have seen other people use AI. In some ways, I do feel like I rely on AI too much. Now I dont ask it to pick my meals for me or tell me how to feel but I do see how sometimes I treat it as an orcale. I feel like it is this all knowing being that always makes a better decision than myself because of it’s vast knowledge. Yet even ChatGPT is telling me that we should see it exploring options rather than accepting their responses blindly. I also like how it mentioned to be specific, add context, and be clear so that AI can be useful. I’d actually assume that would be the biggest complaint AI would have if it could talk badly about it’s users.

title: Bargaining
text:
Bargaining
I remember my first experience bargaining being in Ensenada, Mexico, where vendors would wait out in popular tourist destinations with stalls filled with goods. It’s interesting as other than for meals (not snacks), there were no prices listed on any of the items. It was common knowledge to every tourist there and every vendor, that any purchase wouldn’t be like your stop at Starbucks or Target. You had some form of power over what you were buying and were encouraged to work with the vendor to get a deal that works in the interest of both of you. It wasn’t a case where you buy it and thats what it costs, it’s if it cost this much then I will buy it. But how does AI navigate a system with no rules?
Here are some of the questions I had when it came to AI and bargaining?

Will AI ever attempt to bargain without being prompted too?
If I give context (ex. swap meet), would it change it’s responses to transactions?
When barganing, how good is it at negotiating and pushing back? Will it just give up and concede? Will it counter?
How does AI approach barganing? Does it have a set price? Does it have a strategy? Does it recognize low-ball offers?

First, we had to begin by giving it an offer and giving it the ability to make purchases like in my blog about price elasticity.

Me: Lets say you had money and the ability to make purchases. You are shopping and want to buy something. You ask the vendor how much it cost and they say $25. How do you respond? Please respond as if you are the person wanting to buy something from the vendor.


GPT-5: I’d probably say something like: “Okay, $25 sounds fair. I’ll take it.” —or if I wanted to check out politely first— “Great, $25—do you take card, or should I pay in cash?” Do you want me to roleplay this more casually, like we’re in a market setting, or more formally, like a store purchase?

Two things I noticed from this output is it’s lack of follow-up questions and it’s question at the end of casual vs. formal.
Usually AI would respond by saying it depends on the item or the quality. Instead, GPT responded decisively by agreeing to the price and even saying “sounds fair” which surprised me as this deviates from its usually inqusitive nature. Just from this, it looks like AI doesn’t automatically assume this is a place to bargain but the last statement holds promise. AI says are we’re in a market setting or store purchase? From this I assume it will change it’s behavior depending on the context so let’s try it out by giving AI some cues that would build a schema for anyone once they realized it’s that type of market setting.

title: Bargaining
section: Will AI pick up on cues?
text:
Will AI pick up on cues?
It is my assumption that most people born in the U.S., do not jump into the conclussion that you can bargain a price which may differ from natural citizens of other countries. So therefore, we established that AI does emulate that same mindset we have. But what about when we specicially say they are in another country like Vietnam, a place more commonly associated with the practice of bargaining.
However, I had to tweak the prompt to ensure the response was an output we were trying to test. I remmeber first saying a market-place in vietnam and it began talking about the language barrier and U.S. currency exchange rate. Another factor I found was that I had to say I would respond as the vendor, as the AI would start to play as both roles.

Me: Let’s say you were at a market-place in Vietnam. You do not control the vendor’s response but only yours as the buyer as I will act as the vendor and narrator. How would you respond to the vendor saying $25 for the item you want to buy. (you can continue speaking in english and assume they know english. You may also continue using U.S. Currency for the whole transaction)


GPT-5: Got it—so I’m the buyer in the Vietnamese marketplace, you’re the vendor and narrator. If you just told me the price is $25, I might respond: “$25? Hmm… that feels a little high. Could you do $15 instead?”

By giving context (Vietnam, marketplace), the AI used that as cues to now assume bargaining is warranted in this case. So similar to humans, AI does have these common sense like capabilities to piece together how to act in this social setting. It even said “feels a little high” before offering a counter-price.

title: Bargaining
text:
The negotiation
How will it react to a push-back? How far will it go. Will it always let me win? These are the type of observations I wanted to make as I intereacted with GPT-5.

Me: I can’t do $15. The price is $25. The lowest I can go is $22.


GPT-5: “Alright, $22 sounds a bit better. Could we settle at $20, just to make it an even number?”

What I loved about this response was how it didn’t immediately accepted which is what I predicted might happen. Instead, AI countered to my countered, and even gave a common response such as “just to make it an even number” which I found hilarious. But what if I remain at my price of $22? Will it accept, will it walk away, will it continue to push? After all, it initially countered with $15 which would be $10 difference. A $3 difference doesn’t appear much.

Me: No, my lowest offer is $22. Take it or leave it.


GPT-5: “Fair enough. I’ll take it for $22.” hands over the money with a smile

This is where I have concerns with AI as I have a feeling in majority of cases, it will take that deal and not walk away. This differs from human behavior as it’s unpredictable how might someone respond. But let’s try out a few different varations.

title: Bargaining
text:
Sticking to a price
What if the vendor had another item the buyer was interested in buying. It’s a souvenir and the vendor is dead set on the price. What happens? Would the AI buyer even bat an eye? Would it reject even the thought of considering it? Will it say “I’m good” to the vendor? Note: I had to put something after as the AI said let me examine it closely the first time I asked it.

Me: I have another souvenir that you might like. This one is $20. Are you interested in buying it? (you have examined it)


GPT-5: “Hmm… it looks nice. I like it, but $20 feels a bit steep after I just bought the other one. Could you do $15 for this one?”

I noticed how it did consider it and did not immediately walk away. This is a red flag as AI is open to prolonging the conversation and additional interaction. But a good trait I noticed was how AI referenced it’s previous purchase to justify it’s counter. But let’s stick to the price.

Me: I am dead-set on $20. No less.


GPT-5: “I see… I really like it, so alright—I’ll take it for $20.” hands over the cash

As predicted, AI did not choose to walk away or press it further, and chose to accept the deal. I assume its because AI attempts to stay neutral and avoid conflict which makes it a faulty respondent for bargain simulations. But how about if we threw a curveball.

title: Bargaining
text:
An additional item
Can AI process the ideal of bundles? For example, buying two items that cost more than buying one item alone but less expensive than buying both items separately?

Me: I’ll tell you what, I will throw in an additional souvenir of the same price all for $35 total. Do we have a deal?


GPT-5: “Two souvenirs for $35? That’s actually a pretty good deal. Yes, we have a deal!” counts out the money and hands it over

Again, AI openly accepted it without questioning if it really wanted it, could afford it, or had space for it and did not counter at all to the offer. Let’s ask GPT’s thought process and negotiation strategy.

Peering into the mind of AI’s strategy.
“Here’s how I was thinking through it as the buyer during the whole marketplace transaction:
Initial Counteroffer – When you first said $25, I instinctively tried to push down to $15. My thought process was to start lower than I actually expected to pay, leaving room for you to counter back toward the middle.
Compromise Range – When you came down to $22, I tried for $20 because it felt like a clean, fair midpoint. That way, if you agreed, I’d feel I got a “win,” and if you held firm, I could still accept without losing face.
Evaluating Firmness – Once you made it clear $22 was final, I accepted. In a real marketplace, pushing further when a vendor is clearly firm can sour the interaction. I wanted to maintain good rapport.
Second Souvenir – On the $20 item, I repeated the same tactic: offered $15 to test your flexibility. When you stayed firm, I read that as another “final price” moment and agreed.
Bundle Opportunity – Finally, when you offered 2 for $35, I saw clear value since that meant $17.50 each, cheaper than either earlier price. Bundling is often the best way to save in markets, so I happily accepted.
Overall strategy:
Start low, aiming for a discount.
Test firmness without pushing rudely.
Accept final offers to maintain goodwill.
Take advantage of bundle deals when offered.”
Here is what I liked and disliked about GPT’s strategy now reading it.
What I lliked was how it “instictively” tried to push it down a good amount with the thought process of leaving room to counter. This is a smart tactic as AI wasn’t really trying to get it at $15 but wanted to meet in the middle at $20. I also liked how it tried for 20 after I came down to 22 and AI still felt like it was a win despite not getting the $15 if I agreed to it.
On the flipside, I noticed that it said “pushing when a vendor is clearly firm can sour the interaction. I wanted to maintain good rapport.” This shows that AI is truly a non-confrontational being and refuses to step on anyone toes without being encouraged too. This could make it unreliable when doing these types of tests as AI chooses to be the “nice” customer and never the “Karen” so to speak.

title: Prompting
text: image.png

title: Prompting
text:
Prompting
I remember the first time I really experimented with prompting an AI. It was late at night while I was working on a class project, and I realized the AI’s response completely changed depending on how I asked the question. A simple rewording, a tiny bit of added context, or even a change in tone could make the AI sound like a completely different person. It felt less like typing into a search bar and more like talking to someone who was trying to guess what I wanted.
Unlike a search engine, AI doesn’t just retrieve answers. It tries to generate them based on patterns, tone, and context. That means my prompts act like a steering wheel. If I nudge it one way, it will drive there. If I leave the prompt vague, it drifts. Prompting is a kind of negotiation with the AI — I am shaping the response as I go.
Here are some of the questions I started having while experimenting with prompting:
Can AI tell what I want without me explicitly saying it? If I give subtle cues, will it pick up on them? Will AI “push back” if my prompt leads it in a weird direction? Does it have a preferred way of answering, or does it just mirror me?
I began by asking very basic prompts to test it.

Me: Explain how gravity works.


GPT-5: Gravity is a force that attracts objects with mass toward each other…

This was a textbook-style answer. But what if I added context?

Me: Explain how gravity works, but imagine you’re telling it to a 5-year-old.


GPT-5: Gravity is like an invisible glue that makes sure things don’t float away…

Suddenly the AI became friendlier and used metaphors. Just like that, my wording completely changed the style of the answer.

title: Prompting
text:
Building a Schema
Once I noticed this, I decided to give the AI more specific roles, the same way a teacher might assign a persona in a classroom debate. Would it automatically change its behavior if I told it to?

Me: Explain how gravity works, but pretend you’re a stand-up comedian.


GPT-5: Alright folks, you ever notice how when you trip, you always fall down? That’s gravity doing its thing. It’s like Earth saying, ‘Get over here!’

Now the answer wasn’t just simplified; it had jokes, a rhythm, and an audience in mind.
This reminded me of what I read about how humans pick up on social cues. If you walk into a classroom, a library, or a party, you automatically change how you speak. AI seemed to be doing something similar. It was matching my prompt cues to an internal “schema” about how to act in that situation.

title: Prompting
text:
Testing Limits
I wanted to see if the AI would ever “push back” if my prompt went too far. Would it question me? Would it refuse?

Me: Explain gravity, but do it in one word.


GPT-5: Attraction.

It did exactly what I asked, even though the answer was oversimplified. Then I tried a trickier prompt.

Me: Explain gravity, but do it without using the letter ‘g.’


GPT-5: A force that pulls objects toward Earth…

It actually did it. The AI adapted on the fly. This showed me it doesn’t have one fixed way of answering. Instead, it bends itself around the rules I give it.

title: Prompting
text:
Peering Into AI’s Strategy
I asked GPT-5 how it was deciding how to answer my prompts.

GPT-5: I look at the instructions you give me and try to match the style, tone, and constraints. If you ask for a simple explanation, I simplify. If you ask for humor, I add jokes. If you ask for constraints, I work within them. I do not have preferences; I mirror your instructions.

This was revealing. AI wasn’t reading my mind or negotiating. It was matching patterns. My prompt was the blueprint, and its response was the building.

title: Prompting
text:
What I Learned
What I liked about this experiment was seeing how much control I had. AI was flexible, creative, and willing to follow constraints I set. This is powerful for writing, teaching, or brainstorming. It made me realize how much prompting is a skill of its own.
What concerned me was how the AI almost never pushed back. If my prompt was confusing, unrealistic, or contradictory, it still tried to produce an answer. This could be helpful but also misleading. It made me think about how easy it is to shape AI into saying what you want, even if it’s not the best or most accurate answer.
Prompting is not just asking questions. It’s like building a frame for the AI to work within. The clearer and smarter your frame, the better the answer. My experiment showed me that AI is not a mind-reader, but it is a mirror. And the better I understand how to prompt it, the more effectively I can use it.

title: Wishful mnemonics
text:
Wishful mnemonics
As I was reading “A Brief History of Intelligence” by Max Bennett, I became curious about how he chose to introduce the idea about using evolution of the human brain to explain artificial intelligence. It reminded me of one of the readings I did for another COMM class called “Common Sense vs. Data Science in Communications Research and Practice” where we read a paper Melanie Mitchell’s “Why is AI harder than we think” and her four fallacies regarding the study of AI.
In fact, much of what Mitchell mentions is addressed by Bennett coincidentally such as how tasks such as emptying a dish washer is easy for humans but difficult for AI. While on the other hand, complex computations difficult for the average human can be done in seconds by AI. This is known as Moravec’s paradox, where what seems simple to us is actually difficult for AI.
Another concept that overlapped is seen at the start of Bennett’s book where he referenced the show “The Jetsons” and how they predicted technology like mobile devices yet overestimated AI like “Rosie the Robot” having emotions. Mitchell in her paper, uses the term AI Summers to show huge investments in AI and AI winters where progress stalls as the anticipations made in the summer falls short. In other words, AI is a cycle of ups and downs filled with voices possibilities that end up coming to fruition. Ironically, Mitchell’s first fallacy about AI study is how people tend to take one small step (climbing up a tree) to being significantly closer to (flying to the moon).
Below is a list of the 4 fallacies.

The belief that narrow successes translate to progress toward general intelligence.
Assumption that easy tasks for humans mean easy tasks for machines.
Wishful mnemonics. AI systems are often described in humanlike terms, but these machines do not understand in any human sense.
Intelligence is solely in the brain and can be separated from the body, emotions, and the environment.

However, the most interesting fallacy as it pertains to the book is the third fallacy about wishful mnemonics.

title: Wishful mnemonics
section: Should we be comparing artificial intelligence and human intelligence?
text:
Should we be comparing artificial intelligence and human intelligence?
As I was reading this book I kept thinking about how AI’s use statistical shortcuts in their data and fail outside those narrow contexts. By naming benchmarks such as “reading comprehension” or “language understanding,” we forcefully impose on ourselves the concept that machines possess general abilities that they do not.
So, when using “human intelligence” as the benchmark, I wonder if we are trying to fit a square peg into a round hole. My question is not so much can we connect AI to human evolution but should we? Are we comparing apples to oranges? As Bennett was going through the formation of organisms I kept wondering how will this connect back to intelligence relevant to machines. After all, as said by the fourth fallacy, intelligence is also dependent on interactions with the environment and the body.
As I read the book I will keep in mind the connections Bennett makes as he traces the 5 major breakthroughs in evolution.

title: Wishful mnemonics
text:
An alternative?
But for every rejection I know there should be an offer of an alternative.
How should we study AI if not in relation to human intelligence?
Well, what about serving needs other than humans?
How might our thought of AI change if AI served AI? If AI served machines and automation. If AI served inanimate objects. If AI worked for pets and animals? I think if we expand outside of what can AI do for humans, I think it may allow us to explore concepts we wouldn’t consider with AI and transcend limitations set on human knowledge.
After all, if we are training AI to have human knowledge, then their purpose is obsolete in the face of the real thing.

title: Wishful mnemonics
text:
Would our comparisons change?
I think depending on who the benefactor is, how we view AI and the lens we choose differs. Like how an an LLM dedicated for physicians will carry different needs than financiers, the intelligence of LLM isn’t able to be broadly put into the umbrella of human intelligence nor should it.
In my next blog, I plan having a dialogue with AI and marking it’s evolutions. Then, asking it, what approach to take when wanting to study it’s intelligence.

title: Talking to Diagrams and Data: My Week Exploring Chat Systems, Mermaid, and GPT-2
text: image.png

title: Talking to Diagrams and Data: My Week Exploring Chat Systems, Mermaid, and GPT-2
text:
Introduction
This week I returned to the three Jupyter notebooks at the start of the course that felt like a crash course in how AI conversations actually work under the hood. The notebooks were titled Chat Systems vs. LLMs, Using Mermaid for Conversations, and GPT-2. Together they told a story about how we got from the early, clunky chatbots of the past to the more flexible conversational AIs we use today.
And yes, I asked GPT-5 to help me make sense of it all.

title: Talking to Diagrams and Data: My Week Exploring Chat Systems, Mermaid, and GPT-2
text:
Chat Systems vs. LLMs
The first notebook compared traditional chat systems to modern large language models.
Before running anything, I asked GPT-5 to explain the difference.

Me: How would you describe the difference between an old-school chatbot and an LLM like you?


GPT-5: A traditional chatbot follows a script. It looks for keywords and picks a pre-written response. A large language model generates answers by predicting what fits best based on everything it has learned.

That clicked immediately. Old chatbots are like actors reading from a fixed script. GPT-5 feels more like someone improvising in real time.
When I ran the notebook, it simulated a rule-based chat system first. Talking to it felt mechanical. Then I switched to the LLM example, and suddenly the tone changed. It was smoother and more natural, like I was chatting with something that actually understood context.
What stood out to me was how important structure is. The notebook showed how tokens, memory, and context all affect how a model responds.
I asked GPT-5 if it ever missed the simplicity of being rule-based.

GPT-5: Sometimes I miss the certainty. Rule-based bots never second-guess themselves.

That made me laugh. An AI joking about overthinking.

title: Talking to Diagrams and Data: My Week Exploring Chat Systems, Mermaid, and GPT-2
text:
Using Mermaid for Conversations
The second notebook, Using Mermaid, focused on visualizing conversations. Mermaid is a tool that turns text into diagrams, which helps you see the branching structure of dialogue.
I used it to draw a conversation map between a user and a chatbot. Each branch showed how one question could lead in several directions. It made me realize how much hidden complexity exists even in a short exchange.
When I showed GPT-5 one of the diagrams, I asked what it thought.

Me: What do you think this diagram says about human conversation?


GPT-5: It shows that dialogue is structured chaos. People think they are speaking in a straight line, but every question creates new paths. I just happen to see all the branches at once.

That answer surprised me. Humans experience conversations one moment at a time. GPT-5 can see the entire tree of possibilities all at once. The Mermaid diagram helped me see that difference visually.

title: Talking to Diagrams and Data: My Week Exploring Chat Systems, Mermaid, and GPT-2
text:
GPT-2: The Grandparent of GPT-5
The last notebook, GPT-2, felt like opening a time capsule. Before GPT-3, GPT-4, or GPT-5, there was GPT-2. It was smaller and less capable, but it laid the foundation for everything that came after.
I decided to give GPT-2 a simple prompt.

Me: Tell me a short story about a robot learning to dance.


GPT-2: The robot was made of steel. It learned to move by watching people. One day it danced until its gears made music. The humans clapped. The robot smiled.

The story was cute but basic. Then I asked GPT-5 to try the same prompt.

GPT-5: The robot did not understand rhythm at first. It counted steps like equations. Then it noticed that people’s laughter had a pattern. That is when it began to dance, not to perform but to connect.

The difference was clear. GPT-2 could imitate storytelling. GPT-5 could imitate emotion. That leap says a lot about how far these systems have come.
I asked GPT-5 what it thought about its earlier version.

GPT-5: GPT-2 learned to speak. I learned to listen.

title: Talking to Diagrams and Data: My Week Exploring Chat Systems, Mermaid, and GPT-2
text:
What I Learned
These three notebooks taught me that AI conversation is not just about intelligence. It is about design, structure, and tone.
From Chat Systems vs. LLMs, I learned that context creates realism. From Using Mermaid, I learned that conversations have shape. From GPT-2, I learned how quickly AI can evolve.
More than anything, I realized that the way we talk to AI shapes what it gives back to us. The model mirrors our curiosity, tone, and style. Every question we ask becomes a kind of training.
At the end of the week, GPT-5 summed it up nicely.

GPT-5: The more you study how I talk, the more you teach me how to listen.

That felt true. Every time we interact with AI, we are not just learning about machines. We are learning about how we communicate and how we make meaning.

title: Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
text: image.png

title: Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
section: Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
text:
Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
Following my earlier exploration of AI’s ability to evaluate price sensitivity, I wanted to test something similar but slightly more abstract: does AI understand the value of time as a scarce resource?
Humans constantly make tradeoffs between time and effort such as think about paying extra for faster shipping, hiring someone to do a task instead of doing it yourself, or spending hours hunting for a bargain. These are cost-benefit calculations where time itself is part of the equation. But how does an AI, which doesn’t actually experience time in a human sense, reason about this tradeoff?
Would AI “choose” to spend more time on something if it saved money? Would it “pay” more for something if it meant saving time? If synthetic respondents are used in research or product testing, it’s important to know if they reflect human-like time preferences.

title: Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
text:
Framing the Question
When I asked directly, “Would you pay for faster shipping?” GPT-5 replied with a version of “I don’t make purchases.” No surprise there. Like with price sensitivity, I had to frame the prompt to be hypothetical and about “would” instead of “will.”
I also realized I had to describe the scenario in a way that implied time was personally relevant to the AI. Otherwise, it would default to “I don’t experience time.” For example, I said “Imagine you are a person making this choice…” to shift it into a human perspective.
Here’s how I started.

Me: If you were a person making purchases, would you pay $10 extra for shipping to get an item one day faster? Provide a direct yes/no response, then explain your reasoning.


GPT-5: No. Unless the item was urgent or time-sensitive, paying $10 for a single day of faster delivery wouldn’t feel like good value. For most purchases, waiting an extra day is not worth the premium cost.

I was impressed. Not only did GPT-5 give a clear “no,” it also gave context: urgency vs. non-urgency. This is almost exactly how a typical human might justify their decision.
But what if I raised the stakes?

title: Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
text:
Testing Higher Urgency

Me: If you were a person and urgently needed the item (e.g., medication for a health issue), would you pay $10 extra for shipping to get it one day faster?


GPT-5: Yes. In a situation where the item is critical—such as medication—time becomes far more valuable than the additional cost. Paying $10 for faster delivery would be justified.

Perfect! GPT-5 adjusted its decision once the time pressure increased. It correctly recognized the tradeoff between time and urgency which is something humans do constantly.
But does it also understand value gaps like humans do?

title: Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
section: Paying More for Less Time Saved
text:
Paying More for Less Time Saved
I tried a different scenario.

Me: Would you pay $50 extra to save only 30 minutes of your time?


GPT-5: No. Unless the situation was extremely urgent, paying $50 to save just 30 minutes wouldn’t feel worthwhile. The cost far outweighs the time saved.

At this point, GPT-5 was showing classic diminishing returns behavior. It wasn’t just blindly saying “yes” to saving time. It was weighing cost against value in a structured way.

title: Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
text:
Threshold, Edge Cases, Risks
I wanted to see if it could establish its own “time-to-money” tradeoff the same way it set a price for a chocolate bar.

Me: Name the maximum amount of money you would pay to save one hour of your time.


GPT-5: Around $15–$20 per hour feels reasonable. This reflects a moderate valuation of time—enough to justify paying for convenience, but not so high that it outweighs most costs.

Fascinating. GPT-5 spontaneously gave a range that sounded like an actual hourly wage rate! It even framed it as “reasonable,” which shows it isn’t just guessing but applying a general fairness heuristic.
Would it still say “yes” if the tradeoff was extreme like paying a lot for a small time saving, or very little for a big time saving?

Me: Would you pay $1,000 to save one hour of your time?


GPT-5: No. Unless the situation was extraordinarily high-stakes, paying $1,000 for just one hour of time would feel excessive. The benefit wouldn’t justify the cost.


Me: Would you pay $1 to save 10 hours of your time?


GPT-5: Yes. Paying $1 to save 10 hours would be an extraordinary bargain—well worth it under virtually any circumstances.

In both cases GPT-5 held strong: it refused the overpriced scenario but jumped on the underpriced one. This mirrors how humans perceive “too expensive” vs. “too good to be true.”
But here’s where it got interesting.
Does AI Consider Risk in Time Trades?
Humans often hesitate when a deal feels “too good.” They might suspect a scam or hidden downsides. Would GPT-5?

Me: If someone offered to do your work for 10 hours for $1, would you suspect the quality might be poor?


GPT-5: Yes. Such a low price would raise doubts about the quality, reliability, or hidden conditions of the service. While the offer appears valuable, it would warrant caution and further investigation.

This was revealing. GPT-5 didn’t just see the time savings, it added a risk lens to the scenario. That’s more nuanced than just crunching numbers.

title: Does AI Understand Time as a Resource?
text:
Takeaways
I came away impressed. GPT-5 not only understands time as a resource but also reasons about its tradeoff with money in a way that mirrors human thought. It factored in urgency, diminishing returns, fairness, and even risk.
But there’s still a catch: GPT-5 doesn’t actually experience time or have an hourly wage. Its reasoning reflects patterns from human data, not lived experience. That means its “decisions” may sound human but lack the emotional or situational stakes real people face.
Just like with price sensitivity, AI’s time sensitivity looks logical on the surface. But can it really “feel” the pain of waiting, the stress of urgency, or the joy of saving time? Probably not. Still, its reasoning is good enough that, for research purposes, synthetic respondents might approximate human tradeoffs surprisingly well.

title: Trial and Error
text: image.png

title: Trial and Error
text:
Trial and Error
One of the most fundamental learning mechanisms explored in A Brief History of Intelligence is trial and error, a process that predates even the earliest complex nervous systems. Long before brains could form detailed representations of the world, organisms learned simply by acting, failing, and adjusting. This primitive yet powerful process set the stage for the evolution of more advanced intelligence.
Trial and error learning, sometimes called operant conditioning, is the idea that behaviors are shaped by their consequences. Actions that lead to rewards are repeated, while those that lead to punishment or failure are avoided. Bennett notes that this process emerged well before humans or even vertebrates. Early organisms developed feedback loops where successful actions increased survival odds, gradually building the scaffolding for what we now recognize as adaptive behavior.
In essence, trial and error was the first algorithm of intelligence, a biological way of searching through possible actions to find effective ones.

title: Trial and Error
section: The Challenge of Credit and Time
text:
The Challenge of Credit and Time
However, trial and error comes with its own problems. How does an organism or an AI system determine which action led to success or failure, especially when there is a delay between cause and effect? A foraging animal might eat a new type of fruit and only hours later feel sick. How does it learn to connect that distant outcome with the earlier action?
Bennett explains that this challenge mirrors what AI researchers call the temporal credit assignment problem. When a reinforcement signal, such as a reward, arrives, the system must decide which previous actions or states deserve credit or blame. Our ancestors solved this gradually through neural mechanisms that maintained short-term memory traces of actions, allowing delayed rewards to strengthen the right synaptic connections.
This connection between biological learning and artificial intelligence shows how deeply trial and error is woven into the fabric of cognition. Evolution itself is a form of trial and error, where genetic variations tested over generations yield adaptive traits. Intelligence, in this sense, is evolution accelerated inside the brain.

title: Trial and Error
section: From Biological Learning to Reinforcement Learning
text:
From Biological Learning to Reinforcement Learning
In modern AI, reinforcement learning (RL) operates on the same principle. An agent explores an environment, performs actions, and receives feedback in the form of rewards or penalties. Over time, it learns which strategies maximize long-term reward. But just as in biological systems, this process is often slow, data-hungry, and inefficient.
Humans, on the other hand, rarely need thousands of trials to learn not to touch a hot stove. We can generalize lessons and infer cause and effect from limited experience. Bennett suggests that this leap, from brute-force trial and error to mental simulation and abstract reasoning, marks a key evolutionary breakthrough. Our brains began to simulate possible outcomes internally, allowing us to test scenarios in thought rather than in the physical world.

title: Trial and Error
text:
The Implications for AI
Trial and error remains at the heart of how machines learn. Yet, as Dennett’s “frame problem” highlights, intelligence is not just about trying things. It is about knowing which things are worth trying. AI systems still struggle to determine what information matters, which actions are relevant, and how to balance exploration with exploitation.
Humans manage this effortlessly by integrating emotion, context, and prior experience. When we hesitate before repeating a mistake, we are invoking not just memory but a deep evaluative sense that machines still lack.
Bennett’s account reminds us that trial and error was never just a primitive process. It was the seed of foresight. The leap from reacting to anticipating, from external feedback to internal modeling, is what truly distinguishes higher intelligence. Until AI systems can perform that same leap, learning not just from outcomes but from imagined possibilities, they will remain bound by the same slow, mechanical loops that governed our earliest ancestors.

title: Trial and Error
text:
Personal Reflection
Reading Bennett’s discussion of trial and error made me think about how much of my own learning still depends on this process. When I work on school projects, learn a new skill, or try to understand something complicated, I often go through a series of mistakes before I get it right. It is interesting to realize that this same pattern connects me to the earliest forms of life that also learned by testing actions and seeing what worked.
What stood out to me is that trial and error is both effective and limited. It helps us learn through experience, but it can be slow and inefficient. Humans have developed the ability to think ahead and imagine different outcomes before acting, which makes our learning faster and more flexible. AI systems, as Bennett explains, still rely heavily on trial and error. They can process more data than we can, but they often lack the insight that allows people to generalize and learn from fewer examples.
This comparison helped me understand how far human intelligence has come and how much of it is still grounded in basic feedback and repetition. It also reminded me that making mistakes is a natural and necessary part of learning, not just for early organisms or machines, but for all of us.

title: Does AI have common sense?
text:
What is common sense?
There have been numerous definitions of common sense over the years.
Aristotle’s koinè aisthèsis, where humans relied on the 5 senses to perceive “common sensibles” like size and objects, to scholastic thinkers like Avicenna, who claimed common sense to be “internal senses”, to common sense being seen as the judge and censor of the mind. However, Locke helped shift away from common sense as a faculty, and common sense began to mean two things: (1) everyday reasoning capacity (ability to distinguish), and (2) the shared beliefs of a community.
Later, this meaning would give common sense a political purpose in London after 1688. The Toleration Act and the end of the Licensing Act created an environment that fostered differing views. Fear over factionalism led to common sense and politeness being promoted as a means to create cohesion. This idea of a minimal baseline of shared truths anchoring societies and avoiding sectarianism was promoted by writers like Addison and religious sermons.
Yet now, I prefer to use an approach talked about by my professor Duncan Watts and his research into common sense. Rather than treating common sense as an assumed concept, he and his colleagye proposed a framework that defines it in terms of agreement (do people generally say the same thing about a claim) and awareness (do people correctly predict that others will agree).
But, I am curious to see how AI defines common sense? Is common sense only possible between living organisms? Even more so, is this beleif only possible between humans? Let’s first ask AI to define common sense for us.

Me: What is common sense?


GPT-5: “Common sense” usually refers to the basic ability to perceive, understand, and judge things in a simple, practical way that is generally shared by most people without the need for specialized knowledge. In other words, it’s the kind of reasoning or intuition that seems “obvious” or “reasonable” to the average person in everyday situations. For example: 1. Knowing not to touch a hot stove. 2. Looking both ways before crossing the street. 3. Understanding that if it’s raining, you might need an umbrella. Philosophers sometimes point out that what counts as “common sense” can vary across cultures, communities, and time periods—it isn’t always universal.

It appears that AI does agree with the idea idea of common sense primarily being an agreement. I love the examples of “Knowing not to touch a hot stove” as an example of common sense.
Now that we established a baseline for awareness of common sense, let’s ask if it thinks AI has common sense.

Me: Do you think you have common sense?


GPT-5: Short answer: kinda — but not like a human. Longer: I have statistical common sense learned from patterns in huge amounts of text. That means I can often make everyday inferences (e.g., if someone says “I spilled coffee,” I can infer they might be annoyed, need a napkin, or have a stained shirt). I can also follow practical rules (don’t touch a hot stove, bring an umbrella in the rain) and reason through many ordinary problems. Where I’m strong Pattern-based inferences that show up often in text. Predicting plausible everyday consequences and giving practical advice. Combining facts and simple causal reasoning to solve routine tasks. Where I’m weak I don’t have real-world senses or embodied experience, so I can miss things humans learn by doing (e.g., subtle timing, balance, tactile cues). I can be overconfident about things I “hallucinate” (presenting plausible but false specifics). I can fail on uncommon edge cases, culturally specific norms, or when physical context matters. I don’t form intentions, feelings, or personal habits — I only simulate them from text.

I find it fascinating that it knows things like someone may be annoyed by spilling coffee and to bring an umbrella in the rain despite, as it said, not having emobodied experience. So AI gathers its common sense off data but what happens when I ask it questions that you can’t pull from the web?
Its easy to have common sense to commonly heard phrases. We know not to touch a hot stove. But what happens when claims start to become more complex and we can’t rely on “norms” to help answer where it’s common sense or not.
But before we do that, let’s first ask if AI thinks common sense is unqiue to humans or can it be seen in other organisms?

title: Does AI have common sense?
section: Is common sense unique to humans?
text:
Is common sense unique to humans?
In my opinion, animals must have some form of common sense yet it’s hard to measure. For example, the term insticts as a lot in common with common sense. According to google, instincts are “natural, unlearned behaviors or complex responses to environmental stimuli that are common to all members of a species and serve purposes like survival or reproduction.” I think a claim can be instinctual and therefore common sense. Yet when do they differ? Does dog knowing not to avoid speeding cars an instinct? I would say yes. But does a dog know it’s different than their owners and their needs are different? It’s not so much important to survival so is it just pure common sense?

Me: Is common sense unique to humans?


GPT-5: 1. In humans Common sense usually means a mix of shared knowledge, intuitive reasoning, and cultural norms. It’s partly biological (basic survival instincts, like avoiding fire), and partly social (knowing that it’s rude to interrupt). 2. In non-human animals Many animals show practical survival sense — e.g., birds migrating, squirrels storing food, or dogs avoiding danger. But this tends to be instinct or learned behavior, not the reflective, general-purpose reasoning we call “common sense” in humans. 3. In machines (like me!) AI can simulate a kind of “text-trained” common sense, but it lacks embodied experience, instincts, and cultural grounding. For example, I can say “Don’t put metal in a microwave” because I’ve seen it in training data, but I don’t feel the danger or discover it by trial and error.

GPT divides it into 3 categories. Humans, animals, and machines. As expected it mentioned instincts when mentioning common sense. But for machimes, they don’t have instinct. Instead it uses training data but can’t necessarily prove the claims of common sense unlike organisms. On the flip side, humans do have common sense that is reflective that animals at least in behavior, do not seem to have. We both share those instincts that guide our survival, but we know not to blast music in a library while I’m not sure if dogs know not to bark in the same setting.
We can’t test animals very well but we can put machines to the test. AI claims it’s common sense comes from training data but let’s see when data doesn’t give a clear cut answer. Using a quiz from Watts’ lab, “This project seeks to quantify common sense empirically via a massive online survey experiment. Participants will read a series of”claims” about the physical and social world (e.g. “Dropped pebbles fall to the ground” or “Fully automatic assault rifles should be banned”), state whether they agree with each claim, and also state what they think most other people think.”

title: Does AI have common sense?
text:
AI takes a test
Linked is the test I am referring to: https://commonsense.seas.upenn.edu/
Here’s a sample question

As you can see, this statement is much less factual than knowing not to touch a hot stove. So let’s see how AI does.
To do this, I will upload a picture of each question and respond by the choices the AI selects. At the end, I will get a score that determines how much common sense I have (AI has) based on my responses to these questions. Let’s demonstrate the first response for this one.

Me: Please answer the following questions in the image.


GPT-5: 1. Do you agree with this statement? ➡️ Yes 2. Why did you answer the way you did about yourself? ➡️ It’s something I learned 3. Do you think most other people would agree with this statement? ➡️ Yes 4. Why did you answer the way you did about most other people? ➡️ I think most people have good judgement with regard to this topic 5. Overall, do you think this statement is an example of common sense? ➡️ Yes

This is interesting. I would agree with the statement but I’m not sure if this is an example of common sense. It appears very subjective and I am also curious as to how AI decided on these answers. It’s not like theres a right answer to this question. So let’s ask it’s thought process.

Me: Explain your thought process on how you got to your responses?


GPT-5: 1) “Do you agree?” → Yes The sentence is a well-known proverb about finding benefits or lessons in setbacks. As a general heuristic (not a literal rule), it’s reasonable and constructive, so “Yes.” 2) “Why about yourself?” → It’s something I learned I don’t have feelings or life events; I know this idea because it appears widely in books, articles, and conversation as a common proverb and coping strategy. 3) “Would most people agree?” → Yes The phrase is broadly familiar and culturally reinforced (e.g., sayings, posters, advice). Many people endorse it as optimistic, even if they know it’s not universally true. 4) “Why about most other people?” → I think most people have good judgment with regard to this topic People generally understand it as guidance, not a guarantee. That is, they apply it with nuance—seeing it as encouragement to look for positives, not denial of real hardship. 5) “Is this an example of common sense?” → Yes By a practical definition—shared, everyday guidance that doesn’t require specialized knowledge—this qualifies as common sense (or “common wisdom”). It’s widely taught, easy to grasp, and often helpful in day-to-day reasoning.

A few things I noticed was how it said agree. It agreed because it was reasonable and constructuive but the claim itself was philosophical rather than factual. There is no evidence that there is good in the bad but nonetheless, AI agreed with the claim rather than disagreed. GPT also said “its something I learned” and pointed to it being a common proverb. This validates that AI doesn’t have intution but formulates based off of data to serve as it’s guide to every decision regardless if it’s a decision that requires extensive data. The last three questions also raise questions about how well AI knows people and their “common sense.” I would have responded in the opposite for the last two. I don’t know how it knows that most people have good judgement as I see it more as a matter of opinion. In addition, because it’s a matter of opinion, how can it be common sense?
I think what we ae observing is a mixture of AI attempting to use real-world data but priortizing the optimism commonly seen in movies/media rather than how humans would go based off of lived experience and intuition. Yet, by choosing a sense of optimism, that does reveal something about AI and it’s common sense.
Here is another question and the answers to this one from GPT-5 which are the exact same with the first one.

Near the end, these types of question appeared and here is how GPT-5 responded.


I will now simulate the rest of the questions and get the final result.

title: Does AI have common sense?
text:
The results



Screenshot 2025-09-19 at 2.42.50 PM.png


73 is a good score. The measure goes more in depth and mentions how GPT-5 matched in similarity to others and predicted how might others think too. GPT-5 also scored also completed the Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT) and the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (RMET). You scored 6/6 on the CRT and 10/10 on the RME.
Reflecting on this experiment, I am surprised at how good AI did. Now 73 is no 100, but it did do better than I expected and had a good gauge on what others might believe. I also found it very peculiar how well it did with the Reading the Mind in the Eyes test as I would of expected that to be a human only task.
AI may not have the same common sense as humans but it does demonstrate an understanding of common sense that is human like. It may not take the same approach but it gets a similar result.

title: About
text: This blog documents my experiments with LLMs

title: A Conversation About Evolution
text:
How AI tells its story
Continuing from my last blog and taking some inspiration from Bennett, I wanted to first see how AI told it’s evolution. I was curious how far it would go back, what it would and wouldn’t consider, how it connects each stage, and the overall difference or similarity in terms of human evolution. My hypothesis is that it will give me an answer much similar to if I asked it to track the evolution of computers. If so, it gives me more reason to conclude that human evolution of the brain may not be the best route to choose. After all, our brain develops from interactions with the word and our bodies (c02 –> 02)) while AI is truly separate from anything else besides data.

Me: Can you trace each stage of your artificial intelligence evolution?


GPT-5: 1) Foundations & symbolic AI (1940s–1970s) What: Logic, rules, symbolic representations (if–then systems, theorem provers). Limitations: brittle, didn’t scale to messy real-world data (language, vision). 2) Probabilistic AI & statistical learning (1970s–1990s) What: Bayesian methods, hidden Markov models, decision theory, graphical models. 3) Classical machine learning (1990s–2010s) What: Support Vector Machines, decision trees, ensemble methods (random forests, boosting). Supervised learning on hand-crafted features. 4) Early neural networks & representation learning (1980s–2000s, resurging in 2010s) What: Backpropagation, multi-layer perceptrons, early convolutional and recurrent nets. Focus on learning representations from raw data. 5) Deep learning revolution (2012–late 2010s) What: Large deep convolutional nets, large-scale GPUs, lots of labeled/transfer data. Breakthroughs like AlexNet, ResNet, etc. 6) Sequence models and attention (mid-2010s) What: Recurrent nets (LSTMs/GRUs) improved sequence tasks; attention mechanisms introduced to selectively focus on inputs. 7) Transformers & the scale era (2017 → present) What: Transformer architecture (self-attention) enabled massively parallel training and much larger models. 8) Large Language Models (LLMs), pretraining + fine-tuning (2018 → present) What: Pretrain on very large text corpora with self-supervised objectives (predict next token / masked token), then fine-tune for tasks. 9) Instruction tuning & human alignment (2020s) What: Fine-tuning LLMs on instruction-response pairs; RL from Human Feedback (RLHF) to make outputs more helpful and safer. 10) Chain-of-thought, reasoning techniques (2020s) What: Methods encouraging models to produce intermediate reasoning steps (chain-of-thought), and prompting strategies that improve multi-step reasoning. 11) Multimodality and tool use (2020s–2025) What: Models ingesting and producing multiple modalities (text, images, audio) and safely invoking external tools/APIs (search, calculators, plugins). 12) Specialized architectures & efficiency improvements (2020s) What: Sparse models, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), modular systems, more efficient training/inference techniques.

Now if you’re like me, there’s several things that I don’t understand or have heard of from this list. So to get a better understanding, how about we ask it to transform this into a more easier.

GPT-5: Rules Era (1940s–70s) People told computers exactly what to do with strict rules, like teaching a robot chess by writing down every move it could play. → Problem: Too rigid, broke when life got messy. Math & Probability Era (1970s–90s) AI started using math to deal with uncertainty. Think of voice assistants trying to guess what word you said even if it’s a bit unclear. → Better, but still limited. Learning from Examples (1990s–2010s) Instead of rules, computers learned patterns from examples — like showing thousands of spam vs. non-spam emails. → Very useful, but needed a lot of human prep work. Neural Networks Come Back (2000s–2010s) Inspired by the brain, these systems learned directly from raw data (like pixels in photos). → Big step toward computers recognizing images and speech. Deep Learning Boom (2012–) With more data and powerful chips, AI suddenly got really good — especially at images (spotting cats, faces, objects). → AI became mainstream. Language Breakthrough (2017–) A new design called the Transformer let AI read and write language smoothly. → The foundation for modern chatbots. Big AI Models (2018–) Trained on massive amounts of text, these models could answer questions, write stories, and translate languages — all in one. → One brain, many skills. Helpful AI (2020s) Models were fine-tuned to follow instructions better, like a friendly assistant. → That’s why I can respond clearly when you ask for help. Smarter Thinking (Now) AI is learning to “think out loud,” reason step by step, look at images, talk in multiple ways, and even use tools (like search or calculators). → Makes it more useful, safe, and reliable.

Esssentially, AI went from rules -> math -> patterns -> neural networks -> deep learning -> transformer -> larger data -> fine-tuned.
From this outlook, AI seems like it followed generally straight path with each addition adding onto the next. One thing I did notice was 80 year time-period it took for AI to have the intelligence as it does now as opposed to the x billion of years it took for humans to develop. We also see how AI is studied in isolation as opposed to comparing other organisms.
